results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Miso is an incredibly healthy paste made from soybeans, sea salt, and koji (a mold starter), and often mixed with rice, barley or other grains. And it's delicious. I will introduce shiro-miso (white miso with soy beans), which has a shorter fermentation so that you can start eating after one week. If you like miso, it is a good opportunity to learn how to make your own. Miso soup made with homemade miso is much creamier and tastier.

Each student will leave with a miso pot.

We will also make a miso soup and rice ball onigiri during the class.

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
# Let us improve CityGram.NYC - JOIN US FOR CITYGRAM SATURDAY!

On Sat, Oct 24, from Noon till 7:00 pm, we're going to improve NYC's CityGram notifications!

CityGram.NYC is a geographic notification platform designed to work with open government data. It allows residents to designate area(s) of a city they are interested in and subscribe to one or more topics. For this weekend, we're going to subdivide NYC's 311 data feeds and teach you how to build new notification feeds. 

We are looking for 10 - 15 skilled civic hackers who want to spend a Saturday afternoon learning how to maintain CityGram.NYC and build up its data resources. Our long term goal is build up a dedicated, volunteer support team that can support CityGram. 

## Why would you want to do this:


1. You want to learn about the open data and improve NYC's open data.
2. You're interested in building software that helps people using open data.
3. You'd like to meet people who've built software from open data, and learn from them.

## Things you will learn to do on CityGram Saturday 


1. Write up a user persona and user story outlining why someone would access this CityGram feed.
2. Define the specific data feed
3. Select an noun project icon for your data feed.
4. Build a CityGram services script.
5. Submit a pull request to CityGram's repo.

## NEXT STEPS & to RSVP visit github 

Comment on this GitHub issue with your first & last name, email address, & super power.
results.name: CityGram.NYC Saturday

results.description:
Organizer`s phone number[masked] Katherine

We are living in the city with the most interesting museums of the world so let`s explore them!

This weekend we are going to a guided tour in Metropolitan Museum that will cost you only 1 dollar! How cool is that? You have to remember you need to come earlier around 12:15pm or 12:30 to buy 1 dollar pass and drop your coat to the coat check, use the restroom. Please take care of your comfort beforehand. The tour starts at 12:45pm sharp and lasts for an hour. Please don’t be late! Make sure you have comfortable shoes and able to walk and stand for an hour or so. When we finish we can go for a drink and introduce ourselves, discuss the tour, get new ideas and meet the new friends.  It is very inspiring for many creative people and very relaxing from daily routine.  Everybody is welcome!

The collection of Asian art at the Metropolitan is the largest and most comprehensive in the West. This tour presents ancient and modern selections of the Chinese, Japanese, Korean and, South and Southeast Asian galleries, featuring religious and secular highlights of paintings, prints, sculpture, ceramics, bronzes, jades, lacquerware, textiles, and screens in the permanent collection and special exhibitions. Also featured is the Astor Court, a courtyard modeled after a Ming-dynasty scholar's Chinese garden. Tours are never the same! That means that you can take the tour over and over again. The professional tour guide will tell us the origins, the history, the interesting facts of the items, and we will be able to ask all kinds of questions.

After the tour you don’t have to stay with the group but continue exploration on your own.  The Museum is open until 9pm.

The meeting point: the spot under the clock on your left hand side when you walk into museum.  All the groups are gathering there. Just wait for a 12:45 pm tour.
results.name: This Saturday! Art of Asia in Metropolitan Museum! $1 dollar tour!

results.description:
From Goodreads--

From an author named by The New Yorker as one of the "20 Best American Fiction Writers Under 40," a hilarious, inventive, unforgettable collection of stories.

His remarkable first collection of stories was hailed by The New York Times as "the debut of an exciting new voice in fiction." Garrison Keillor called him wildly funny, pure, generous--all that a great humorist should be." With this new collection, George Saunders takes us even further into the shocking, uproarious and oddly familiar landscape of his imagination.

The stories in Pastoralia are set in a slightly skewed version of America, where elements of contemporary life have been merged, twisted, and amplified, casting their absurdity-and our humanity-in a startling new light. Whether he writes a gothic morality tale in which a male exotic dancer is haunted by his maiden aunt from beyond the grave, or about a self-help guru who tells his followers his mission is to discover who's been "crapping in your oatmeal," Saunders's stories are both indelibly strange and vividly real.

George Saunders has been identified as a writer in the tradition of Mark Twain, Thomas Pynchon, and Kurt Vonnegut--"a savage satirist with a sentimental streak," said The New York Times. In this new collection, Saunders brings greater wisdom and maturity to the worldview he established with CivilWarLand in Bad Decline, leaving no doubt about his place as the brilliant successor to these writers.
results.name: October -- Pastoralia by George Saunders

results.description:
VISIT TO THE AFRICAN BURIAL GROUND-90 Minutes.

October 24,2015 @ 12:30 pm

A Sacred Space in Manhattan

From about the 1690s until 1794, both free and enslaved Africans were buried in a 6.6-acre burial ground in Lower Manhattan, outside the boundaries of the settlement of New Amsterdam, later known as New York. Lost to history due to landfill and development, the grounds were rediscovered in 1991 as a consequence of the planned construction of a Federal office building.

Tour/Visit includes the Site film

A self guided tour of the exhibits

A Memorial talk-20 minutes

We will then grab a bite to eat and get acquainted.

Location/Direction: 

The African Burial Ground National Monument is located on the first floor of the Ted Weiss Federal Building located at 290 Broadway in Lower Manhattan; close to Foley Square and just north of City Hall. The cross streets are Duane Street and Reade Street.

The African Burial Ground National Monument is easily accessible by public transportation. Driving and parking in New York City is significantly more difficult.

By Car

If you are driving on the east side of Manhattan-leave Franklin Delanor Roosevelt (FDR) Drive at the City Hall exit. Proceed west on surface streets to Broadway. The African Burial Ground National Monument is located just north of City Hall at 290 Broadway.

If you are on the west side of Manhattan-leave the West Side Highway/West Street at Chambers Street. Drive east on surface streets until you reach Broadway. The African Burial Ground National Monument is located just north of City hall at 290 Broadway.

By Public Transportation

The African Burial Ground National Monument is accessible by multiple subway lines within a 4-block radius, including:

1, 2, 3 [Chambers Street]
A, C [Chambers Street]
R [City Hall]
4, 5, 6 [Brooklyn Bridge/City Hall]
J, Z [Chambers Street]

( A $8.00 Annual  Membership Dues are required from ALL members for  first event.This Membership Dues  help defray the organizers dues payments for our Club). 

See you there!  

  Laurel
results.name: Visit to The African Burial Ground

Hi everyone,

As I stated in the group email, I am planning the Second Anniversary Meetup as a historic walking tour of Harlem. Two years ago when I started the group, one of our first meetups was a historic tour of the Apollo. I thought it would be a great experience to take it back to where our group began. Through the prompt RSVP's to this event, it seems to be popular one. 

Please note that while I am using the organization "Free Tours By Foot" the tour is not actually free for large private tours such as ours. The cost of the event will be $13.00 which will include (full two hour tour, group tip, and meetup cost of one dollar which is used to keep the group going). 

Please note that I must submit payment to the company in advance for the group. If you RSVP'ED as a YES and still plan to attend you must send payment no later than Thursday, September 3rd. This will give everyone two weeks to send me your payment. Please note that if I do not get payment by the deadline, I will delete you from the event and will defer to the WAITING LIST. 

If you are on the WAITING LIST please DO NOT send payment until you are officially confirmed for the event. 

PAYMENT OPTIONS:

Two choices:

1. Pay Online using Venmo- easy online tool to use which is very popular with many members. Simply find my name JOHN CIFERNI and you can transfer payment of 13.00 right away. 

2. Pay with Check payable to CASH- via mail. Please send to my address:

John Ciferni

799 Mountain Avenue Unit B

Springfield, NJ 07081. 

Once I get payment I will confirm. 

Thanks,

John

Harlem Historic Walking Tours:

From Website " Free Tours By Foot"


Although world famous, Harlem may be New York’s best kept secret with some of the city’s most interesting architecture, food, music and people. Harlem’s history is also one of the city’s most dramatic, having gone through many ethnic, cultural and socioeconomic changes over the past roughly 400 years, which have resulted in a diverse array of places of worship, theaters, homes and eating establishments.

- See more at:

http://www.freetoursbyfoot.com/new-york-tours/walking-tours/harlem/#sthash.hGoZF1ow.dpuf

s to follow soon.

Two hour Harlem tour and discover the streets where Ella Fitzgerald, Duke Ellington and other cutting edge Harlem Renaissance players put American music on the world map and where Fidel Castro slept after being kicked out of a midtown hotel for having chickens in his room.

Come hungry, if you want to treat yourself to some great soul food after the tour!  If food is your avenue for discovery, then consider our Harlem Food Tour.  We’ll also show you some places where you could visit to experience a live gospel service.

- See more at:

http://www.freetoursbyfoot.com/new-york-tours/walking-tours/harlem/#sthash.hGoZF1ow.dpuf
results.name: Historic Walking Tour Harlem

results.description:
*Check out CNY's first Kickstarter Campaign!

----

“How could they see anything but the shadows if they were never allowed to move their heads?” 


   ― Plato, The Republic

Knowledge and Reason:


Many people—though not all—want to “know" themselves better and learn more about the world around them.  I assume that many of you are reading this description right now because you’re interested in understanding yourself and the world better (among other things, of course).  For some of you, this is why the above question has caught your attention; for some of you it may be part of the “reason” why you participate in intellectual discussion groups on Meetup.


Many people also believe that higher-level reasoning processes—such as the critical thinking skills of analysis and evaluation—can help them achieve this level of understanding.  (It’s not necessarily that anyone thinks that these are the sole methods of achieving understanding; reasoning processes are, however, a very important, predominant means of doing so by some standards.) 

We’ll consider this lofty topic through a series of questions that will get us closer and closer to comprehending the relationship between knowledge and reason. 

Some of the questions we will consider include, but are not limited to:

·  What might it mean to “understand” one’s self?  To understand the world around us?

·  How might the processes of reasoning help us to accomplish this understanding? 

·  What is the relationship between (and distinction among) reasoning on the one hand and other forms of "knowing" on the other—such as intuition, imagination, and emotions?  (For example, is there a false dichotomy between reasoning and emotions, reasoning and imagination; which might have a greater influence over the other: reasoning over emotion or vice versa, is it possible to separate the relationship between the two?) 

·  What might science in general and scientific reasoning in particular have to teach us about this topic? 

·  What are the limitations of reasoning in terms of helping us understand ourselves? Is there a danger in relying predominately on reasoning in this respect? 

We will be gathered together for one day, for two and a half hours, to discuss these and other questions.   

The format of our discussion will be as follows:

·  We will consider some definitions of reason and knowledge and their relationships;

·  We will discuss and debate the extent to which we can know ourselves and the world around us more accurately and more effectively;

·  We will consider the implications and applications of our discussion to our lives and those around us;

·  We will share some past examples of how we think we have reasoned our way to a greater self-understanding in our lives; or, conversely, we will provide evidence and reasoning to explain how we think we can’t!

About the Moderator:

Rolando is an educator of educators.  He works with teachers from the four major disciplines—Math, Science, English, and History—to craft, hone, and assess their pedagogical practices.  He has hosted other discussion groups on Meetup.  In his spare time, he enjoys reading, writing, and ruminating on the relationship between knowledge and reasoning. . . .
results.name: How Can Reasoning Help Us to Better Understand Ourselves & the World?

results.description:
After several books along a bloody, murdery theme, let's move our attention toward love. And as most of the love-themed books we've read in the past have been written by men, let's see a lady's take on the topic. This is a great novel for those of you who have expressed interested in meta-fiction. Also, after several books in the 500-page range, this book is a very manageable 240. 

Lydia Davis is considered one of the most original minds in American fiction today. Her numerous accolades include a MacAuthor Fellowship (the "genius" grant), a Guggenheim Fellowship, the Man Booker International Award, and the Whiting Writer's Award. She has been a finalist for the PEN/Hemingway Award and National Book Award. Davis is also a French scholar and has translated works by Flaubert and Proust, whose works have influenced her own.

True to its title, The End of the Story begins at the end of the love affair at its heart. Flashing forward a year, the nameless narrator, a writer and university teachers, goes on to tell us of her failed attempts to find "him" (also nameless) in a strange city. The hope is all the more urgent in that she is writing a novel about the very novel we are reading.

Like many contemporary novels, The End of the Story is in large part about itself, about the painful process of its own making. It is about the strange paradox under which all writers labor, namely that the very attempt to clarify our experience can end up obscuring it. The simplicity and precision of Davis' prose (often described as poetic) only intensifies this sense of the profound elusiveness of life and love.
results.name: Lydia Davis' The End of the Story--MacAuthor Fellowship, Man Booker Award

results.description:
Fur season is upon us once again, and as such, Caring Activists Against Fur (CAAF), will be making our immutable opposition to the horrific Chinese fur trade known to those unscrupulous cretins whose livelihood is the confinement, torture and extraordinarily brutal extermination of innocent beings - all in the name of fickle "luxury" and transient, superfluous "fashion." CAAF will be staging another anti-fur demonstration at Bloomingdale's Dept. Store in New York City, NY.

Come and add your voice to a burgeoning group of energetic animal activists whose prime directive is to elevate public awareness about the plight of innumerable defenseless foxes, minks, raccoons, dogs and cats</a>, and other mammal victims of the gruesome Chinese fur trade, who are violently and systematically removed from their natural habitats, corralled into inescapable death camps, crammed into tiny, filthy cages for months in ALL weather conditions, beaten, stomped on, anally electrocuted, gassed, bludgeoned to death, even SKINNED ALIVE so that affluent first-world consumers can gleefully, obliviously parade around, morbidly draped in the skins that were quite literally, ripped off these animals' backs as they helplessly writhed in overwhelming shock and agony 'til the final throes of death overtake them. This often means the poor, pathetic, skinless creatures will writhe in mortal agony for minutes or hours! These helpless animals are tortured and killed in the most horrifically cruel ways imaginable - all for vain, pretentious, human notions of "luxury apparel" and "fashion."

Jump into the ongoing campaign to STOP this insanity and work toward the total abolition of the global fur industry. Come out and HELP US make a vocal, public impact for the animals trapped and languishing in this insidious death trade, and to send a meaningful message to the heartless people who line their pockets with blood and entrails, who build their posh castles with the unspeakable screams of terror and suffering from countless innocent beings. For those unfamiliar with the realities of the horrible global fur trade, please take a few minutes to watch the following (Warning: graphic imagery!)

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mkw_OUnVXqM">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mkw_OUnVXqM<a href="http://savefrom.net/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3Dmkw_OUnVXqM&utm_source=ff-sf&utm_medium=extensions&utm_campaign=link_modifier"></a>

Disgusting? Horrible? Unforgivable? Agreed, so PLEASE come and help us to vocalize our extreme objection to this inexcusable, retrograde, medieval barbarism, to discourage/deter potential fur-shoppers from patronizing this retail dealer in death and torture, to enlighten the public to the grim realities behind their whimsical, self-deluding notions of fashion, and to encourage them to make more compassionate choices in shopping for winter apparel. In a world with so many great (and more economical) cruelty-free fabrics and styles, there really is ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE for this ongoing madness.

WHERE: Bloomingdale's, Lexington Ave. by 59th St, NYC
WHEN: Saturday, October 24th, 2015.
TIME: From 1:00pm - 3:00pm.

We will have plenty of signs, literature and relevant props to share with interested members of the general public. All YOU need to bring is yourself and your voice to speak up for the voiceless, who cannot articulate their own wish to freely live out their lives under the sun, to frolic and to bear young, to behave in accordance with their own natures, with no interference from our species.

No more cages!!!!
results.name: CAAF "Don't Buy Fur!" demo@ Bloomingdale's on Lexington Ave in New York City!!

•What might it mean to “understand” one’s self? To understand the world around us?


• How might the processes of reasoning help us to accomplish this understanding?


•  What is the relationship between (and distinction among) reasoning on the one hand and other forms of knowing on the other—such as intuition, imagination, and emotions? (For example, is there a false dichotomy between reasoning and emotions, reasoning and imagination; which might have a greater influence over the other: reasoning over emotion or vice versa, is it possible to separate the relationship between the two?)

• What might science in general and scientific reasoning in particular have to teach us about this topic? 


• What are the limitations of reasoning in terms of helping us understand ourselves? Is there a danger in relying predominately on reasoning in this respect? 

We will be gathered together for one day, for two and a half hours, to discuss these and other questions.

The format of our discussion will be as follows:
• We will consider some definitions of reason and knowledge and their relationships;
• We will discuss and debate the extent to which we can know ourselves and the world around us more accurately and more effectively;
• We will consider the implications and applications of our discussion to our lives and those around us;
• We will share some past examples of how we think we have reasoned our way to a greater self-understanding in our lives; or, conversely, we will provide evidence and reasoning to explain how we think we can’t!

About the Moderator:
Rolando is an educator of educators. He works with teachers from the four major disciplines—Math, Science, English, and History—to craft, hone, and assess their pedagogical practices. He has hosted other discussion groups on Meetup. In his spare time, he enjoys reading, writing, and ruminating on the relationship between self-knowledge and reasoning. . . .
results.name: How Can Reasoning Help Us to Better Understand Ourselves & the World?

results.description:
Ladies and gentleman, it is time for our yearly tradition. Please RSVP and join us as the Woodside-Sunnyside Runners present the

                Fifth Annual Halloween Pub Run!

Our adventure kicks off on Saturday, October 24th at 1:00pm, as we embark on a journey through four (or more) pubs while very casually running about 3ish miles through Sunnyside and Woodside. Be sure to dress creatively! There is a costume contest at the end. We’ll be offered drink specials by each of our pub hosts, and have a fun afternoon adventure here in Queens.

And, as is our tradition, we will not only enjoy ourselves, but also work to raise money for a local non-profit. This year, we're going to raise funds in support of Sunnyside Community Services, a great neighborhood organization that provides a broad range of services to approximately 14,000 people per year including children, youth, adults, and seniors.

About the Pub Run
We began our Halloween tradition five years ago, which was unfortunately timed to coincide with a freak, slushy October blizzard (two of the participants actually enjoyed the adventure so much that they are now married). Last year, 55+ runners participated with some awesome costumes, and we raised a couple thousand dollars for a local non-profit while enjoying beverages and great company. This year, we will do the same!

Please RSVP now, prepare your costume and plan to join us. The more the merrier, so bring anybody else you can fool into thinking this is something that sane people do. Please do RSVP so we can get an idea of how many people to expect (it’s easier to encourage bar owners to give us good stuff if we have lots of people signed up). 

Are you afraid that you might not be able to run 3ish miles in a Halloween costume while drinking? You should be, but not really. We’ll be stopping a bunch of times (at each pub), making the actual running distances quite short. We’re also extremely casual and will not leave anybody behind. The run between pubs will be comfortable-pace and friendly, suitable for just about everybody from beginning runners to marathoners and everything in-between. If you have friends or relatives who wish to join us and they insist upon only walking, please contact your organizer who can provide them with an appropriate route.

Additionally, we won't force you to drink at every pub if you don’t wish - we’re all about safety and enjoyment! There will be plenty of water and food opportunities available to balance things out.
  
You won’t know which pubs we’ll hit until we arrive at each. This makes things more fun, keeps the group together and lets everybody focus on socializing and enjoying the adventure.

NOTE TO THE MARATHONERS: If you are planning to run the NYC Marathon a week after this event and are not drinking, but would love to participate, your organizer needs your help. Give back to the group that has supported you through your training by volunteering to help out. Message your organizer for details.

-- 
Disclaimer: Any running event is a strenuous activity. Add alcohol to the equation and it makes it that much more challenging. Please ensure that you have an adequate fitness level for this sort of activity before planning to participate. You participate in this event at your own risk, but we really don’t want anybody to get hurt (i.e., we care about you). If you have questions or concerns, please message the organizer! 


- - - - - -
Please see our full calendar of events
http://www.woodsidesunnysiderunners.com/events/calendar/
connect with us on Google+
http://www.google.com/+WoodsideSunnysideRunners
like us on Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/WoodsideSunnysideRunners
and follow us on Instagram
https://instagram.com/woodsidesunnysiderunners/
- - - - - -

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

Learn to Salsa New York Style with Yrma Arias at El Taller! This style of Salsa, "On 2", has gained popularity over the last decade in NYC. The classes will focus on the look and feel of the dance - with an emphasis on timing, footwork and partner work. Classes will provide instruction and repetition of the steps ‘Shines’, introduce the importance of the leader/follower connection, and provide practical techniques for the Latin Motion. Particular attention is paid to rhythm and musicality. This is an enjoyable class designed for people of all ages. The most important lesson is to have fun! What to bring: A great attitude and comfortable clothes and shoes that allow you to move!


When you arrive at 215 E. 99th Street, press the El T button on the intercom and we'll buzz you right in!

Dominies Hoek has a deal on Mimosas with brunch. This is the one on Vernon Blvd. The last time I was there, around $20 included your brunch and mimosas after tax and tip maybe . Easiest thing to do is bring $20 cash. This place can get crowded. If we get there at 1:30 and it is packed, we can go to another place on Vernon Blvd. Bring extra cash if you want to drink if we go to other places after brunch.

From there, we can go to LIC Flea.

After LIC Flea, we can go to The Creek And The Cave. Usually in the afternoon, there is open mic for comedians http://creeklic.com/events/the-amateur-hour-2015-10-03/ . You may get to see a unknown and future famous comedian there. http://thecreekandthecave.com/


After The Creek and The Cave? Well, we can keep going if you want. I will take this meetup all day, all night, and even until the sun comes up on Sunday morning where we go full circle to get brunch again. Some of my meetups have been epic and lasted 12-14 hours until where you can get a 2nd breakfast or 2nd brunch the following day when the meetup started the day earlier. However, I will leave it up to you if you want to go for a epic one. haha

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

This walk is an art studio walk plus an optional walk in West Chelsea. This is moderate paced (not slow paced) with a distance up to 4 miles. If you think that you will be lagging behind, then this type of walk is not good for you.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup is John, the event host, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photograph. Thank you again.

Description: We'll explore the Elizabeth Foundation Open Artist Studios, which has about 70 artist opening their studios to the public and showing their work. All of these art studios are located in one building on several floors. The artists don't charge admission to their art studios. We'll stop in some of these art studios and get a rare, intimate view of the artists' working environment. We can also talk to the artists about what they do. This art walk features painting, photography, ceramics, mixed-media, sculpture, and printmaking. 

We'll also go to art studios and galleries on 3 or 4 floors in a nearby building.

Another stop will be an an art gallery featuring contemporary surrealism. The gallery is focused on figurative paintings and sculptures featured by an unconventional interpretation of the living existence.

Below is titled "Gate Keeper" by Yoko D'Holbachie

We also will be going to a printmaking shop, where there will be a demonstration on printmaking. According to them, this is the largest printmaking workspace (which includes art studios and exhibitions) in the United States.

If there is time and interest, we'll then walk down to the West Chelsea neighborhood, which is just south of the Garment District. We'll look at old industrial architecture/artifacts as well as dazzling new buildings designed by Pritzker award-winning architects. We will finish between 5:00 PM and 5:30 PM.

Below was congested West Chelsea before the High Line (Photo Friends of the Highline [Unidentified Photographer])


Because of accidents, the New York City Council on December 4, 1850 passed a law requiring urban cowboys to escort the locomotives. (Photos Library of Congress [George Grantham Bain 1911])

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (after lunch) at 1:30 PM.

Meeting Place: The meeting place is outside of the entrance to the Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Center Building at 323 West 39th Street, located on the north side of the street between 8th and 9th Avenues. Before the walk, restrooms are available in several locations in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, which is a few blocks away from the meeting place. There will also be places for restrooms stops along the way, including in the Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Center Building.

Transportation Options: Take the A, C, or E subway trains to the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 42nd Street/8th Avenue and then walk a couple of blocks south OR take the 1, 2, 3, 7, N, or R subway trains to the Times Square Station and then walk southwest for about two blocks.

Finishing Time/Place: If there is time and interest, we'll walk down the West Chelsea and finish between 5:00 PM and 5:30 PM  at West 23rd Street near the Hudson River waterfront.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

Only heavy rain will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is heavy rain, or the forecast is for heavy rain, I will post a cancellation notice on Saturday morning. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel this walk, I will also post a cancellation notice in the Discussion Board.

Below is titled "Lemon-Lime" by Scott Teplin.

Below is titled " Marbelous" by Hong Seon Jang.

results.description:
Blossom in Chelsea is celebrating its tenth anniversary in this month, October. This is actually owner Pamela Elizabeth's very first Blossom restaurant, opened in 2005.  The place has gone through many transformations since then.  We've already gone to the two Blossom locations on the Upper West Side, so it makes sense now to go downtown and try the one in Chelsea.

Black=eyed Pea Cake

For brunch, try the Cape Cod cakes ($11), croquettes of hijiki seaweed, herbs and spices served with a can't-believe-it's-not-mayonnaise-based vegan tartar sauce. The tofu scramble with vegetables and soy sausage, ($13 with toast plus salad or fries) is popular as is the soy bacon cheeseburger ($13) There's also French toast, crisp on the outside, soft on the inside with a side of tempeh. On the lunch menu choose from the caesar salad, which delivers hand-made capers and a nutty flavor or the "Black-eyed Pea Cake".a favorite which is a breaded and fried potato-and-black-eyed-pea medallion covered in a spicy chipotle sauce.

View the menu at:

http://www.blossomnyc.com/blossom-restaurant-2

results.description:
***THE BUILDING AND ROOM NUMBER WILL BE UPDATED THE DAY OF THE EVENT***

It's ironic that we live in one of the wealthiest countries in the world, but we always have money problems. We can work hard all our lives but retire poor.


Nobody teaches us how to manage our money in school. Financial issues are not often discussed, and financial products not always explained.

We all want comfortable retirement, but few have a plan. We may be active spenders but passive savers.

We need to change and the task won't be easy. But we need understanding first.

Join us for this life changing presentation. Some concepts to be covered include...

-Building a Financial Foundation

-The Wealth Formula

-The X-Curve

-The Importance of Paying Yourself First

-Simple VS Compunding Interest

& more...

My great friends & I will present a powerful message about how good it feels to own your future instead of fearing it, and what you can do to start taking ownership of yours.

I look forward to meeting all who attend!
results.name: How MoneyWorks & Building Your Financial Future

results.description:
SCHEDULE

• 2:00 to 3:30pm: Introductory Lecture

• 3:30 - 3:45 pm: Break

• 3:45 to 4:45pm: Meditation Instruction (all levels) 

Make sure you are on time - Doors close at 2:15pm for Lecture and 3:45pm for Meditation. Click here for directions 

~ ABOUT THIS LECTURE ~

• The Instructor for this class will be Richie.

• To prepare for this lecture, please study the following and the links belows. 

Eight Verses for Training the Mind by Geshe Langri Tangpa [masked] 

Composed by the Buddhist Master Langri Tangpa [masked]), Eight Verses for Training the Mind is a highly revered text from the Mahayana Lojong (mind training) tradition. These instructions offer essential practices for cultivating the awakening mind of compassion, wisdom, and love. This eight-verse lojong enshrines the very heart of Dharma, revealing the true essence of the Mahayana path to liberation. Even a single line of this practice can be seen as encapsulating the entire teaching of the Buddha. For even a single statement of this mind training practice has the incredible power to help us subdue our self-oriented behavior and mental afflictions. 

The fundamental theme of mind training practice is the profound reorientation of our basic attitude, both toward our own self and toward our fellow human beings, as well as toward the events around us. The goal of mind training practice is the radical transformation of our thoughts, attitudes, and habits. Presently, we tend to cherish the welfare of our own self at the expense of all others. However, the mind training teaching challenges us to reverse this process. This involves a deep understanding of others as true friends, and the recognition that our true enemy lies inside of ourselves, not outside. 

As we practice these lojong teachings in daily life, we train the mind to embrace reality in a completely wholesome, wise, and compassionate way. These excellent practices help us purify our negativity and awaken the heart by giving us a way to transform adversity, conflict, and hardship into a direct opportunity for spiritual growth. In this way, rather than perceiving difficult people or adverse circumstances in our lives as an obstacle, tragedy, or punishment, we now meet these experiences with deep compassion, wisdom, and skill—using them as our actual practice on the path to enlightenment. 

By way of these treasured practices we eliminate our competitive, selfish, and emotionally reactive nature, as well as our false and exaggerated concepts of self (also called self-grasping and self-cherishing). It is important to understand that the greed, jealousy, anger, pride, selfishness, and attachment, which cause us so much suffering, are actually misperceptions of reality, not inherent conditions of our mind. Therefore, these precious lojong practices can purify our misperceptions and delusions completely, revealing the natural radiance, clarity, wisdom, and compassion of our true nature.

by Geshe Langri Thangpa

By thinking of all sentient beings
As more precious than a wish-fulfilling jewel
For accomplishing the highest aim,
I will always hold them dear.

Whenever I’m in the company of others,
I will regard myself as the lowest among all,
And from the depths of my heart
Cherish others as supreme.

In my every action, I will watch my mind,
And the moment destructive emotions arise,
I will confront them strongly and avert them,
Since they will hurt both me and others.

Whenever I see ill-natured beings,
Or those overwhelmed by heavy misdeeds or suffering,
I will cherish them as something rare,
As though I’d found a priceless treasure.

Whenever someone out of envy
Does me wrong by attacking or belittling me,
I will take defeat upon myself,
And give the victory to others.

Even when someone I have helped,
Or in whom I have placed great hopes
Mistreats me very unjustly,
I will view that person as a true spiritual teacher.

In brief, directly or indirectly,
I will offer help and happiness to all my mothers,
And secretly take upon myself
All their hurt and suffering.

I will learn to keep all these practices
Untainted by thoughts of the eight worldly concerns.
May I recognize all things as like illusions,
And, without attachment, gain freedom from bondage.


http://www.prisonmindfulness.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/EightVerses.pdf

http://www.lamayeshe.com/article/commentary-eight-verses-thought-transformation

results.description:
Donald Rumsfeld famously said, “There are known knowns; there are things we know we know. We also know there are known unknowns; that is to say we know there are some things we do not know. But there are also unknown unknowns—the  ones we don’t know we don’t know.” From a philosophical perspective, how do we know what we don’t know? How do we go about transforming “known unknowns” into “known knowns” and “unknown unknowns” into “known unknowns”? Is one person’s unknown another person’s cognitive bias? How might a psychoanalytic understanding of dynamic mental function play a role here? And what role does mystery play in our lives, from scientific, religious, and other perspectives?

NOTE: For full bios, see: http://www.helixcenter.org/roundtables/the-realm-of-mystery/

Participants:

Carol Rovane

Professor of Philosophy, Columbia University

Carol Rovane is Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, where she has served as Director of Graduate Studies and Chair of the Philosophy Department, and was recently awarded the Lenfest Distinguished Faculty Award.  She publishes widely in the areas of metaphysics, philosophy of mind, philosophy of action and ethics, and has authored two books:  The… read more »

Michael S. Turner

Bruce V. and Diana M. Rauner Distinguished Service Professor of Physics, the University of Chicago

Michael S. Turner is a theoretical astrophysicist and the Bruce V. and Diana M. Rauner Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago. He is also Director of the Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics at Chicago, which he helped to establish, and formerly served as the President of the American Physical Society. He received his… read more »

Elliot Wolfson

Marsha and Jay Glazer Chair Endowed Chair in Jewish Studies, the University of California, Santa Barbara

Elliot R. Wolfson, a Fellow of the American Academy of Jewish Research and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, is the Marsha and Jay Glazer Chair Endowed Chair in Jewish Studies at the University of California, Santa Barbara. His main area of scholarly research is the history of Jewish mysticism but he has brought… read more »

Susan Wolfson

Professor of English, Princeton University

Susan Wolfson has taught at UC Berkeley, Rutgers University, and is now Professor of English at Princeton University. She’s a specialist in the literature of British Romanticism, the era of “enlightenment” quests for knowledge and new philosophies of social freedom and social responsibility. She teaches regularly in this field, and when possible, Shakespeare, and Milton’s… read more »

results.description:
It is with great pleasure that I can announce this meetup. Please join us for this very special discussion on
AGELESS WISDOM IN A TIME OF TRANSITION

As we witness the events unfolding on our planet, we know the future stands in the balance. We are entering a time long foretold in the prophetic writings of the world, when great events are due to occur and enlightened teachers will again come forward. Humanity is fast approaching the threshold of a spiritual and cultural transformation--unprecedented in the history of life on Earth.

The ideas in this talk are based on the 24 volumes of Ageless Wisdom teachings written by Alice Bailey written in conjunction with Tibetan teacher Djwhal Khul. This teaching, embodying ancient principles passed down through the centuries in oral, symbolic and writtern form, gives a deeper understanding of the subjective factors underlying outer events. It also provides a safe and scientific method of spiritual training that will continue to stand the test of time. BIO

Kathy Newburn has worked for many years at Lucis Trust, New York www.lucistrust.org (the organization founded by Alice and Foster Bailey),. She is the author of A Planetary Awakening: Reflections on the Writings of the Tibetan in the Works of Alice A. Bailey. Kathy has reached out to share the Ageless Wisdom tradition with people in many parts of the world. Kathy has a particular interest in esoteric astrology. www.kathynewburn.com
results.name: Ageless Wisdom in a Time of Transition - Discussion w/Kathy Newburn

results.description:
Early Bird Fee of $88 extended - to closing. (Thank you Monica!)

The Theme  


I'll bring a few different color shirts to best complement the art chosen for each round.  I'll be wearing tight leather pants, black heeled boots.  I'll have a professional MUA come and do my makeup - smoky eyes with wavy hair.   

All of that with the Bushwick graffiti art in the background PLUS... giant bubbles. 

I bought a large bubble wand and solution for this shoot through Amazon, it's being delivered to me this Wednesday.  Hopefully I will have enough time to practice practice practice!  No promises on how big these will be but I'll give you my best of lifestyle outdoor fun!  YOU SHOULD GET GREAT PICTURES! SIGN UP NOW!!  :D

The Place

We’ll shoot at The Bushwick Collective. Tons of fabulous graffiti art.

ABOUT ME: 

Hi, my name is Monica, It's my second event here at TMD and love having the freedom to be creative.  If you have any ideas you would like to shoot, message me and I'll see what I can do to make it happen!   

I'm an accountant turned professional model. I like to have fun with photoshoots! I'm not afraid to try new looks, poses, etc., feel free to direct me or fix my hair how you would like it. Don't be shy! Tell me the look you are going for! Get the best shots possible and direct me well.  Everyone here has something they want to learn or practice or try something new, many are here to get experience directing the subjects (me).  Yes: I expect many of you will tell me to move left when you mean right and to twist when you mean turn... haha, that is all the fun! If you are communicative and have fun with the shoot, you will be taking with you memories to last a lifetime! :) 

Follow me @

https://instagram.com/topxrahman/


The Shoot: 

Photographers will shoot in 10 minute increments, with the option to use waiting photographer(s) as assistant(s). The shoot should last between 2-1/2 to 3 hours. depending on how long wardrobe changes (if any) and my breaks are. 

The Fees: 

The Model (me): $50

The MUA (her):   $20 ($80/4 ~ 20 per photographer)  

TMD Booking fee (the glue) : $45 ($18 if booked early before advertising campaign)

Total Regular Fee:  $ 115 

Book NOW for EARLY BIRD $88 extended - to closing. 


---->>>>   *******  A NOTE FROM JOHN: 

Thank you MONICA!  - No ads were placed this time around as requested by Monica. She believes she'll convince some of the members to sign up.  Let's hope so!  

• ================= 


HOW TO PAY:

Payment for this meetup is done through TheModel'sDen Paypal account.  After you RSVP an invoice will be sent within a few hours for payment. 

Invoices will be sent to the email you will provide.    

Balance of $50 in cash is due the day of the event, plus any surcharges you may have agreed to. -  Please bring exact change.

==================== 

CANCELLATIONS: 

Please note! -  Events are not cancelled because of inclement weather.  I will make the decision no less than 2 hours before the event.  You will be notified by all the following means:  posting on this event page; email; a text message and a call if no response is received from you.

ALWAYS Check this event page 2 hours before the event starts to be kept informed of the status.  

==================== 

Why TMD? 

So many groups are crowded with photographers, a massive paparazzi nightmare.  At TMD, it's just the model, you and at the most 3 other photographers that help and assist each other.  There will be times for paparazzi shoots. Those are for promotional purposes.  

Models don't expect or request copies of the images. And photographers are not obligated to share.  Sure, if you happen to have a spectacular image feel free to post it for everyone to see.

You get what you pay for: TMD models are interviewed and if their portfolio is lacking, they are test shot.  

At TMD, the models are more than just models, they are business people, hospitable & creative. They understand that photographers are here to learn, experiment and have fun!
results.name: Edgy Urban Chic TMD-Photoshoot with HUGE bubbles and ME!

results.description:
Bulgogi is made from thin slices of sirloin or other prime cuts of beef. Before cooking, the meat is marinated to enhance its flavor and tenderness with a mixture of soy sauce, sugar, sesame oil, garlic, pepper, and other ingredients such as scallions, ginger, onions or mushrooms, especially white button mushrooms or matsutake. Pureed pears and onions are often used as tenderizers. Sometimes, cellophane noodles are added to the dish, which varies by the region and specific recipe.

Bulgogi is traditionally grilled, but pan-cooking has become popular as well. Whole cloves of garlic, sliced onions and chopped green peppers are often grilled or fried with the meat. This dish is sometimes served with a side of lettuce or other leafy vegetable, which is used to wrap a slice of cooked meat, often along with a dab of ssamjang, or other side dishes, and then eaten together. 

***Please note***

- Please give me your email address and phone number right after RSVP then we will send you an invoice from Paypal when we can pay through that.

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation


• no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.
results.name: Saturday Ultimate Frisbee (Anderson Park)

Meet on the american football field (near the entrance close to the public restrooms)!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:30. We typically start 20-30 minutes after 3:30. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.
results.name: Saturday Pick-up Parade grounds 3:30 PM

results.description:
We have a very exciting opportunity. I have spoken with Mike Fox coordinator of the group "Progressive Democrats of America" and we have the ability to form our own chapter right here on Staten Island and get logistical support from a nationwide organization committed to getting Bernie Sanders elected president of the United States.


In order to become a full chapter of Progressive Democrats of America, we must arrange an in-person MeetUp in order to assign the following leadership roles. Please comment here or on Facebook or message me to let me know if you are interested and we can set up an event to meet together and organize. (Let me know if a different date/time would work better for people!)


We need people to fill the following leadership roles:

Outreach Coordinator: the gregarious person who goes to lots of meetings/events. Makes connections with coalition partners, as well as builds individual membership.

Events Coordinator. If the team decides to meet physically, E.C. in charge of securing facility. Also in charge of any other events, rallies, protests from a logistics standpoint. This is a great job for an engineer, accountant, project manager... Those wonderful right angle folks who make lists. :)

Media/Social Media Coordinator If standard media coordinator, we ask that person to have a track record of success at getting media to show up. If none, no worries. National will handle it, and the local can focus on social media with a focus on bringing in new members.

Fundraising Coordinator. Person doesn't have to be selling constantly. Just set a modest goal and attain it. I can show you how to raise a 1-2K with a single We Want Bernie meetup of 20 people.
results.name: Becoming a Chapter of Progressive Democrats of America!

group.name: Staten Island Progressive Democrats of America

results.description:
This month's topic is "What is Radical Feminism?" The point is to see where we agree, where we disagree, and how we can come together.

Here are some readings to get you started:

http://www.feministes-radicales.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/mary-daly-gyn-ecology-the-metaethics-of-radical-feminism.pdf (it's a little old, but written by one of the mothers of modern radical feminism and fascinating; it refers to an earlier work by the same author, which is the next link).


http://www.feministes-radicales.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Mary-Daly-Beyond-God-the-Father-Toward-a-Philosophy-of-Womens-Liberation.pdf


http://deepgreenresistance.org/en/who-we-are/faqs/radical-feminism-faqs (an FAQ by a self-described radical feminist organization, which is a bit controversial).


https://feminsttheoryreadinggroup.wordpress.com/2010/11/23/marilyn-frye-the-politics-of-reality-oppression/ (not specifically on radical feminism, but on the topic of oppression, from a radical feminist perspective, by one of my favorite authors).


I look forward to the discussion!

results.description:
It's Meetup Time Again!

For our second meetup we will once again gather to introduce ourselves, meet the current members, welcome new ones, and perhaps come with questions about how/when/where to begin your Icelandic language studies, if you so desire!  

If you've brushed up a bit on your Icelandic and would like to try your hand at speaking, then this is the place to be.  

Perhaps you're a native speaker and haven't spoken Icelandic in ages, then this is the group to join. 

Or are you a student and would like to ask questions about a particular grammar topic? Then this meetup is for you!

Whatever your level, from novice to native, please join us for a casual, relaxed afternoon of both English and Icelandic.  Any language enthusiast will be sure to enjoy themselves here, and what better language than Icelandic?  

I will once again be providing printed materials for those who are interested, so after you RSVP, feel free to email me.  

Come on out, don't be shy, dust off your language skills and come meet plenty of cool people in a relaxed and friendly environment.  

We had so much fun last time and worked up quite an appetite, as you can see here!

Tell your friends and see you all on Saturday!

Franca
results.name: Icelandic Language Saturday Afternoon on the Lower East Side!

results.description:
Let's explore the Met together every other Saturday with as little pressure as possible.

Go in the 81st entrance (not up the big stairs), and head straight back to the Uris Center for Education. We'll be at the set of benches with the number 8 above them inside the room. At 4:15pm we will split up.

We'll decide who will go see what with whom, wander galleries, and meet at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30pm for cocktails, mocktails, and small plates to chat. We'll get tables at 5:40pm.

Everyone is responsible for their own admission and tab. I recommend you bring cash for your tab to make settling the check easier.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be at the set of benches with the number 8 above them inside the Center For Education room, which is straight ahead when you get past coat check. At 4:15pm we will split up. Then meet up at the north entrance to the Balcony Bar at 5:30.

results.description:
Hi everyone!

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up. Also, please bring a white t-shirt, a red t-shirt, lots of water and be ready to have fun!

We also created a map of the field location since it can be tricky to find: Field Location Map.


If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!


Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

No ball hogging

The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:Field F in Central Park  can be accessed from west 97th street or east 97th street on either side Central Park. We also created a map of the field location since it can be tricky to find: Field Location Map

Directions: By train: From the West side take the B or C to 96th street stop. From the east side take the 6 train to 96th street stop St.

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals: If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee: Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring: A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. Please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds: If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for a future game. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will receive an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has openned up:). Please RSVP as soon as you get that e-mail since everyone on the waiting list will get the same e-mail. The first person who RSVP's takes the spot! Also check our Calendar for other games

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Currently photos can be uploaded and shared to facebook and twitter or at lytro.com. This seminar will guide you through understanding focus control, lenses, and depth of field as well as introduce you to hands on use of the Lytro camera. results.description:
10/24: 4:45-7pm

Hello, hello! About one month ago, our city and the world had a lot of religious-based activities with the Papal visit, Yom Kippur, Eid ul Adha, happening in one week. This I found interesting and gave rise to the thought of having this meetup relating religion (or a lackthereof) to Happiness.

We have many questions to explore and will keep an even-flow convo over the subject of how following religion, not following, and/or creating our own spiritual practice ties into our happiness levels. How do we direct our consciousness out to the world, what guides our actions and ultimately takes tolls on our happiness? Do we live life through a religious lens or lackthereof? Do we have spirit? Does a who/what enable each of our spirits to continue? We will explore these and hopefully many others provided time. To attend, please read below.


Note: by choosing to attend, you are agreeing to be respectful and sensitive to the believers and non-believers at the table (meaning no eye rolling, sighs, firm stances that indirectly insult, denigrating remarks, or passive aggressiveness whatsoever. We are all functional adults and will behave as one functional cohesive unit).

- As there likely be far opposites in this conversational theme, I will remind you that you are not attending to preach that God/Jesus loves all, to convince others that God does or doesn't exist, or to promote or push other dogmatic ideas and positions on others. You WILL be asked to leave otherwise. Nevertheless, we will have a stimulating and interesting conversation! All attending will be asked to share their life experience(s) in the religion arena and how they connect to happiness; we will also branch the conversation globally.


*Check out CNY's first Kickstarter Campaign!


----

A Conversation About Happiness

Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y

</a> CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level
153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

From 5:00pm-7:30pm (it's okay to arrive late or leave early.). Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

<a href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.335.9655&rep=rep1&type=pdf">Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages
